text.text_translated:
Culture is how people live and think.  
Differences are ways things are not the same.  
National culture can shape how we behave.  
But we also learn from our region and community.  
We learn from our age.  
We learn if we are a man or a woman.  
We learn from our work culture.  
We learn from our own life.  
More knowledge of differences in behaviour and expectations helps avoid communication problems.  
But wrong ideas about culture can hurt business relationships.  
We keep this knowledge in mind.  
We must not say all people from one country are the same.

feedback.feedback: FAIL: Meaning Preservation Failure. The MeaningBERT score of 0.6695 is below the required 0.75, indicating the text loses the core nuance about how cultural stereotypes can harm business relationships and the varied influences (corporate culture, individual experiences). FAIL: Fidelity Failure. The BERTScore of 0.8586 is below the required 0.90, showing key terms like "miscommunication", "pigeonhole" and the full list of influences have been dropped or oversimplified. Suggestion: Reintroduce phrases like "miscommunication" and "pigeonhole the individuals", restore mention of "corporate culture" and "individual experiences", and add back details about cultural stereotypes harming relationships to improve fidelity and meaning.

best_attempt.text_translated:
Culture is how people live.  
Differences are when things are not the same.  
It helps to know that people expect different things.  
This idea helps us avoid misunderstandings.  
But wrong ideas about people can hurt our work with others.  
Culture in each country can shape how we act.  
Culture can shape how we think.  
Where we live also affects how we act.  
Our groups of friends also affect how we act.  
Being a boy or a girl also makes a difference.  
The way a company works also affects us.  
Our own experiences also affect us.  
We should keep these ideas in mind.  
But we must not group all people from one country.
